passages.text: ing tactics after summer

- A September ECB rate cut is not on the cards, but we expect markets to reflect greater optionality for an October cut than is currently priced in (around 3bp); tactically receive Oct25 ECB &STR which offers asymmetric upside- Stay received 1Yx1Y &STR on medium term, but reduced, downside risks considerations; keep longs in 98.125/98.3125 Dec25 Euribor call spread versus selling 98.0625 Dec25 Euribor put- Enter Z5/Z6 conditional bull steepener via Dec25 front and 1Y midcurve calls- Keep 2s/10s conditional bear steepener- 10s/30s curve appears only marginally too steep versus fundamental drivers. Keep medium-term steepening bias- 1Yx1Y/15Yx15Y is too flat versus 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y and beta-weighted box trade is attractive on RV considerations- Hold Dec25 SOFR put spread (96/96.1825) versus selling OTM Euribor put- Front-end swap spreads are expected to stay in a narrow range; Keep tactical Sep25 Schatz &STR swap spread widener, which also historically has been a good hedge against sharp widening of OAT/Bund spreads even though the current relationship is weak- Favour Dec25 conditional Bund bull widener as an attractive risk-off hedge- Stay tactically neutral on Bund spreads with spreads being driven by risk-off and supply considerations- Enter Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepener on supportive valuations and RV considerations- Stay in 3Mx(1Yx1Y) unhedged straddles- Enter equi-notional 6Mx5Y/1Yx5Y expiry curve steepener

The &STR 1Y forward yields see- sawed over the last two weeks on shifting risk sentiment, but are overall lower across the curve with a decent outperformance of the belly (Figure 1). A relatively dovish Fed rhetoric at Jackson Hole, where Chair Powell further opened the door for a September cut, and French political noise were the primary drivers of the rally. Anecdotal evidence suggests that flows were mixed with some real money receiving at the ultra- long end, which was broadly counterbalanced by hedge funds' interest in long- end steepeners.
Figure 1: ESTR 1Y forward yields declined over the week with a decent outperformance of the belly of the curve
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 2: The ESTR curve is pricing 0bp and 3bp of cumulative easing by September and October meetings
Source: J.P. Morgan.

The ESTR curve is currently pricing 0bp, 3bp, and 9bp of cumulative easing by September, October, and December meetings, respectively (Figure 2). Recently, ECB rhetoric has shifted in a hawkish direction, with the central bank being in a "good position" with respect to policy rates even though its easing bias remains (Figure 3). We agree that a September cut is not on the cards but we believe that a cut in October is a possibility even though market pricing of such a move is minimal. Our baseline is for ECB to deliver one final cut in October, although the bar for an ease is high. Recent media articles have mentioned that ECB sources see rates remaining on hold in September given growth has surprised to the upside, the EU- US trade deal is not causing "major economic concerns", and inflation data are in line with the June forecast (Figure 4).
Figure 3: ECB rhetoric has shifted in the hawkish direction over the past few weeks
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 4: A September cut is unlikely but we believe that October meeting should price more optionality of a cut
Selected excerpts from recent ECB commentary;
Source: J.P. Morgan.

However, our economists' call for an October cut is driven by several factors (see here). First, the ECB core inflation forecast is currently undershooting the \(2\%\) target for both 2026 & 2027 and is at target only for headline in 2027. Indeed, market pricing for HICP inflation
Figure 5: Inflation market continues to price a target undershoot over the next 2-3 years
Rolling 1Yx1Y, 2Yx1Y, and 3Yx1Y HICP swaps; since 1 Jan 2025; %
Source: J.P. Morgan.

We continue to receive 1Yx1Y ESTR that we have been recommending for the past few weeks, which has moved in a narrow 7bp range since the ECB's July meeting (Figure 6). We acknowledge that the bar for a large rally in 1Yx1Y ESTR is high and we expect this rate to continue to range trade. While the upside to receiving is limited, we believe that this offers asymmetric upside from current levels, as the ESTR curve is only pricing a cumulative easing of around 20bp by mid- 2026. With the ECB still maintaining an easing bias, we believe that the market will continue to price some easing which is likely to increase if output were to start to weaken or inflation prints over the coming months are more benign than ECB's forecast. Thus, we see limited risk of a sharp sell- off in 1Yx1Y ESTR.
Along similar lines, we keep 98.125/98.3125 Dec25 Euribor call spread versus selling 98.0625 Dec25 Euribor put, which is also expected to benefit from the expected asymmetry in front- end yields.

The Euribor curve has flattened sharply over the past few days with Dec25/Dec26 flattening around 5bp since our last publication two weeks ago (Figure 7). We had turned tactically neutral on this curve two weeks ago. With the curve now inverted, we have a bias towards some steepening of the curve. We believe that if increased ECB easing expectations are priced into the curve it will likely be front loaded into 4Q25 or 1Q26. The Dec25/Dec26 curve exhibits a strong negative directionality versus yields and is currently too flat on a 3M

regression basis (Figure 8). We recommend Dec25/Dec26 conditional bull steepeners via Dec25 Euribor calls (front and 1Y midcurve calls) (see Trade Recommendations). Dec25 options on Dec25 futures (front options) are trading relatively cheap in implied volatility terms versus those on Dec26 futures (1Y midcurve options) which allows us to enter the trade at around 3bp better than forwards, after adjusting for net credit using ATM calls.
Figure 7: The Dec25/Dec26 Euribor curve has flattened sharply over the past few days...
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Figure 8: ...and now appears too flat versus yields; enter Dec25/Dec26 conditional bull steepeners via Dec25 front and 1Y midcurve calls Dec25/Dec26 Euribor curve regressed against Dec25 Euribor yield; past 3M; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.

The 2s/10s swap curve overall flattened around 4bp with 10Y swap yields declining around 7bp. Overall, the 2s/10s curve continues to exhibit positive directionality versus yields on a regression basis, a dynamic we expect to continue. We continue to hold 2s/10s conditional bear- steepener via 3M payers.

Further out the curve, the 10s/30s swap curve has continued the gradual steepening seen over 2025 and is now close to the steepest level seen since the ECB started its tightening cycle in early 2022 (Figure 9). The steepening over the last few months has been driven by a combination of structural and technical factors. For instance, increased correlation to US curve, positioning ahead of the Dutch pension fund transition from DB to DC schemes, which will require lesser and potentially shorter- dated hedges, have steepened the curve.
Figure 9: The 10s/30s swap curve has steepened broadly in a monotonic fashion over the past few months 10s/30s swap curve; since 1 Jan 2025; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Figure 10: The 10s/30s swap curve appears only marginally too steep in our long-term fair value model 10s/30s swap curve regressed against 1) 3Yx1Y swap rate \((X_{1}\) , quadratic fit), 2) VIX \((X_{2})\) 3) 10s/30s USD swap curve \((X_{3})\) , 4) ECB balance sheet as a \(\%\) of GDP \((X_{4})\) , 5) ECB Jan22 meeting dummy and Fed's Dec23 meeting dummy \((X_{5}\) & \(X_{6})\) ; since 1 Jan 2017; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Interestingly, despite the recent steepening, the 10s/30s swap curve now appears only around 5bp too steep versus its fundamental drivers in our long- term fair value model versus appearing around 12- 15bp too steep a few weeks ago (Figure 10). This correction in the residual can be largely explained by the fact that the EUR swap curve has lagged the recent steepening of the USD curve, which has itself been driven by concerns around fiscal term premium and Fed independence (see here) (Figure 11).

Looking ahead, we have a steepening bias on the 10s/30s curve but refrain from outright positioning. Our medium term steepening bias is primarily supported by the fact that Dutch pension fund based flows will likely begin over the coming months as we get closer to the transition date of \(1^{\text{st}}\) Jan 2026 for a large majority of funds. We do caution that these funds are likely to be opportunistic in unwinding or reducing structural hedges and additionally have a 12M period to adjust their hedges post transition which would eliminate the need for immediate transition flows. Nevertheless, we note market participants will continue to anticipate these flows and potentially add to steepeners on any material flattening of the curve. Additionally, our steepening bias on the USD curve is supportive of Euro curve steepening even though the beta has declined.

Figure 11: The Euro swap curve has lagged the recent steepening of the USD curve, which has been driven by concerns around Fed independence 10s/30s EUR swap curve regressed against 10s/30s USD swap curve; past 3M; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 12: We keep a medium term steepening bias but refrain from outright positioning on unsupportive seasonals in September
Source: J.P. Morgan.

On the other hand, some near- term flattening of the curve cannot be fully ruled out. For instance, Dutch pension funds typically announce indexation of pension payouts based on the September inflation print. With Dutch inflation still above \(2\%\) , we expect these funds to announce further increase in payouts this year. Historically, these funds then typically receive in long- end swaps (a 10s/30s flattener) to lock coverage ratios. A repeat of this dynamic could exert some flattening pressure on the curve. Of course, there exists a nontrivial chance that, due to already high policy funding ratios and high interest rate hedge exposures, indexation- based receiving could be smaller than seen previously. Nevertheless, this remains a risk to medium- term steepeners. Empirically, the 10s/30s curve tends to flatten a few bps over the month of September (Figure 12).

A few weeks ago, we had favoured 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y swap curve steepener versus 10s/30s flattener on a beta- adjusted basis on RV considerations. The 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y swap curve now appears 3bp too steep versus 10s/30s and we turn neutral on this relative steepening bias (Figure 13). Instead, we now find 1Yx1Y/15Yx15Y swap curve too flat versus 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y and favour 1Yx1Y/15Yx15Y swap curve steepeners versus a beta- weighted amount of 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y steepeners on RV considerations (Figure 14).
Figure 13: Turn neutral on the relative steepening bias of 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y swap curve versus 10s/30s
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 14: 1Yx1Y/15Yx15Y is too flat versus 2Yx2Y/10Yx10Y and beta-weighted box trade is attractive on RV considerations
Source: J.P. Morgan.

German swap spreads were overall mixed over the past two weeks, with a decent outperformance of Bobl & Bund spreads relative to wings (Figure 15). The Bobl/Buxl €STR swap spread curve flattened around 4bp since our last publication two weeks ago. Anecdotal evidence suggests some profit taking in tactical intermediate spread narrowers which were initiated going into the start of the issuance season. Swap spread volatility has increased marginally but still remains at overall low levels (Figure 16).
Figure 15: German swap spreads were mixed over the past two weeks with a decent outperformance of intermediate spreads relative to wings
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 16: Swap spread volatility has increased modestly over the past few days but still remains at overall low levels
Source: J.P. Morgan.

German swap spreads have exhibited limited volatility in the latest OAT/Bund spread widening episode, which was driven by PM Bayrou's call for a confidence vote. Specifically, current volatility of swap spreads pales significantly in comparison to the sharp increase seen during the surprise election announcement in June 2024. As we have discussed here.

we find the recent repricing of political uncertainty risk premia in French spreads to be broadly fair. More importantly, we expect the 10Y OAT/Bund spread to stay in a 75- 85bp range until there is further clarity on the direction of political developments. In our view, the limited volatility of German swap spreads potentially embeds this expectation of limited volatility in French spreads. Nevertheless, in the event of a large widening of French spreads, we would expect German swap spreads to widen as well, despite limited correlation currently. In Figure 17, we show the betas of various German swap spreads versus 10Y OAT/Bund spreads during past episodes of sharp widening in French spreads. While the relationship is currently broadly non-existent, historically, German swap spreads tend to exhibit a decent beta (and R-squared) to French spreads during these two episodes. For instance, Schatz spreads moved with a beta of around 50% to French spreads during the sharp widening seen in June 2024 when Macron surprisingly announced the parliamentary elections. Admittedly, the reaction of German swap spreads this time around has been rather muted but we believe that Schatz swap spread widener still offers a good hedge against a tail risk of significant widening in French spreads.

Figure 17: Historically, Schatz swap spreads tend to exhibit decent beta to OAT/Bund widening episodes - a dynamic we expect to repeat this time around if French spreads widen significantly from here 1M regression statistics from regressing various German swap spreads versus 10Y OAT/Bund spread during past French spread widening episodes; %

EventSchatzBollBundNameStart DateBeta (%)R-sq (%)Beta (%)Trump wins 2016 US Presidential ElectionNov-165853402017 French Presidential ElectionMar-174689312018 Italian General ElectionMay-18997478COVID-19 Risk-offFeb-20617929Expectations of faster Fed normalizationJan-22234881992024 French electionsJan-24478242*Liberation Day* Risk-offApr-25958769French PM Bayou calls for confidence voteAug-25-23-1
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Schatz &STR swap spreads at around - 10bp is now close to the lower end of our expected trading range but appears broadly fair in our long- term fair value model (Figure 18). As we have discussed previously, we believe that there is limited downside risk to wideners from current levels and we hold on to our Schatz &STR spread wideners that we have been recommending over the past few weeks.

Figure 18: Schatz swap spreads are hovering around the lows of our expected trading range and are broadly fair in our long-term model. We keep Schatz €STR swap spread widener as a good hedge against any tail risk of French spread widening with limited downside given current valuations
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Schatz swap spread regressed against 1) German RFR richness to €STR \((X_{s})\) , 2) 1Yx1Y swap rate \((X_{s})\) , 3) 10Y BTP/Bund spread \((X_{s})\) , 4) rolling front Schatz implied volatility \((X_{s})\) , 5) Dummy for ECB Oct23 and TLTRO-III Sep24 repayment \((X_{s}\) and \(X_{s}\) ); since 1 Jan 2015; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Additionally, conditional Bund bull wideners also offer attractive risk- off hedges against any escalation in risk- off sentiment. Bund spreads continue to exhibit a strong negative directionality versus yields, which will likely exacerbate if yields decline rapidly on any risk- off move. The options market is not pricing recent directionality (implied directionality of around \(17\%\) versus delivered directionality of around \(35\%\) ) (Figure 19). We favour tactical Dec25 Bund bull widener as a risk- off hedge.
Figure 19: Favour Dec25 Bund bull widener as a risk-off hedge Bund swap spread regressed against Bund invoice yield; past 3M; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 20: Swapped issuance activity this time around is playing to script and we expect a continued increase over the coming weeks
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Historical daily averages of swapped issuance activity versus 2025 split per month; Ebn/ day
2025Past 5YPast 10YJanuary5.15.14.7February3.43.02.8March2.52.52.5April1.92.42.5May3.92.72.5June3.42.62.2July0.81.31.5August*1.01.51.2September2.92.6October2.32.2November2.22.1December0.20.3
\\*Current August data is as of \(27^{\mathrm{th}}\) August 2025. Source: Dealogic and J.P.Morgan.

In addition to the volatility of French spreads, the evolution of issuance will also be a short- term driver of intermediate spreads. As seen in Figure 20, swapped issuance activity tends to pick up pace towards the end of August and continues on over the next few weeks. Issuance activity this time around is broadly following historical patterns and we expect this to continue increasing over the coming weeks; we also show the typical monthly averages of these swapped issuance activity across the calendar year versus that seen in 2025. All else equal, this increase in swapped issuance activity over the coming weeks should exert a narrowing pressure on intermediate swap spreads. However, as we have discussed at length before, pre- positioning in anticipation of these flows tends to lead to narrower spreads already before issuance picks up. Bund spreads typically exhibit some volatility around end- August/September while maintaining the overall broad narrowing trend (Figure 21). While this is supportive of a modest narrowing bias, we refrain from outright positioning given lingering risks around French politics and also going into US payroll data next week (see above).

Figure 21: Bund spreads tend to exhibit some volatility around end-August/September while maintaining the overall narrowing trend; we stay tactically neutral on Bund spreadsCurrent versus average Bund spreads (vs 6s) around end-August; past 10Y; bp
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 22: Enter Dec25 Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepener which is trading too flat versus fundamental drivers on a short-term model
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Instead, we recommend Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepener as an alternative. The Bund/Buxl swap spread curve has flattened around 4- 5bp over the month of August. On a short- term basis, the swap spread curve appears too flat versus 10s/30s swap curve, after adjusting for Bund spreads and the US tariff announcement in early April (Figure 22). Our medium- term swap spread steepening bias is supportive of swap spread curve steepening positions as well. Overall, we recommend Dec25 Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepener (see Trade Recommendations).

Implied volatility declined marginally across the curve with a small flattening of the volatility curve across tails over the past two weeks (Figure 23). Anecdotal evidence suggests that flows were light with bias towards short volatility positions. 1M delivered volatility also declined around 0.3- 0.5bp/day across the curve which essentially reflects the large move post July ECB moving out of the sample. 1M delivered volatility is still around 0.6- 0.8bp/day below current implies across the curve (Figure 24).
Figure 23: Implied volatility curve flattened marginally over the past two weeks 2W change in implied volatility (3M expiry) versus current and 2W ago level of vol curve; bp/day
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 24: 1M delivered volatility is still well below current implieds Current 3M expiry implied volatility versus 1M delivered volatility; bp/day
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Figure 25: Since the jump on US tariff announcements, implieds have declined broadly in a monotonic fashion with a decent steepening of the volatility curve across tails 3Mx2Y and 3Mx10Y implied volatility; since 1 Jan 2025; bp/day
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Implieds are now at their YTD lows; they have declined broadly in a monotonic fashion since the spike around Trump's tariff announcement in early April with a decent steepening of the curve across tails (Figure 25). Implieds are optically cheap on valuations but we expect implieds to remain sticky around current levels. However, we continue to stay short volatility, especially via structures that exploit mean reversion in front- end yields (Figure 26). Admittedly, we have a bullish duration bias (see above) but we highlight that we do not expect front- end yields to decline materially from current levels and range trading remains a strong conviction theme. The bar for ECB to cut policy rates further is high and it will require proof of data which is likely to be gradual over the coming weeks, as is reflected in our baseline scenario of a final cut coming only in October. In other words, even though implied volatility is likely to remain sticky, we do expect delivered volatility to stay muted over the coming weeks. To this effect, we highlight the following attractive strategies.
Figure 26: Mean reversion is strong in Euro area yields; we prefer range trading short volatility strategies...
Source: J.P. Morgan.
Figure 27: ...and we stay short 3Mx(1Yx1Y) unhedged straddles Current implied vol (bp/day), straddle premium (bp of notional), breakeven moves (bp), and upper/lower breakeven levels (\%);
Data as of \(28^{\mathrm{th}}\) August 2025. Source: J.P. Morgan.

First, we hold short in 3Mx(1Yx1Y) unhedged straddles - a theme that we have been following over the past few months and re- struck into new 3M options in our last publication (see here). As we had highlighted, the breakeven ranges are wide and will require material shift in ECB policy rate path expectations for yields to breach these levels (Figure 27).

Second, we also like expiry curve steepers on front/intermediate tails (2- 10Y). For instance, buying ATMF 1Yx5Y straddles versus selling an equi- notional amount of ATMF 6Mx5Y straddles are long vega/short gamma at inception by construction. The weighted implied volatility spread (weighted by vega to obtain equi- notional exposure) exhibits a strong positive correlation to implieds but with a small beta (Figure 28). The weighted vol spread is close to the low end of its recent range and appears marginally too cheap versus implies. On the curve, we prefer these structures in the 5Y sector where we expect delivered volatility to be relatively muted as ECB is expected to remain on the sidelines over the next few weeks. The main risk to this trade would come from a jump in risk- off sentiment which could lead to some flattening of the expiry curve and/or large yield moves. Overall, we recommend buying 1Yx5Y ATMF straddles versus selling an equi- notional amount of 6Mx5Y ATMF straddles (see Trade Recommendations).
Figure 28: Enter equi-notional 6Mx5Y/1Yx5Y expiry curve steepeners to benefit from expected low delivered volatility and potential pick-up in implieds
Figure 29: We favour selling forward volatility agreements via synthetic replicates

Third, we favour short synthetic forward volatility structures constructed using a triangle of swaptions. As we have discussed previously, these synthetic replicates have residual gamma and vega exposures even though standard forward volatility agreements (FVA) have zero gamma exposure. In Figure 29, we present a list of attractive synthetic volatility constructs that are overall short gamma/long vega at inception. We also highlight that short FVAs are short correlation by construction. Correlation between the front and intermediate yields (say 1Yx1Y vs 5Yx5Y) is around \(60\%\) when measured on daily changes over the past 3M. However, with front- end yields expected to remain sticky, we believe that risk bias for the correlation to stay low or decline even further. Amongst the structures presented, we favour shorts in 6Mx1Yx5Y which can be constructed via selling 6Mx1Y and 18Mx5Y straddles versus buying 6Mx6Y straddles, which appears attractive.

- Stay in 2s/10s conditional bear steepener via 3M OTM payersHold longs in €100mn 2.804% 3Mx10Y payer (ATMF strike 2.694%, notification date 20 Oct 2025, maturity date 22nd Oct 2025) versus short €453.3mn 2.07% 3Mx2Y payer (ATMF strike 2.02%, notification date 20 Oct 2025, maturity date 22nd Oct 2027) to remain in a conditional bear steepener at 73.4bp versus spot and forward curve at 58.6bp and 59.5bp, respectively; P&L since inception (18th July 2025): -24.5bp of notional;

- Enter Dec25 Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepenerSell 1000 Dec25 Bund futures versus receiving €127.2mn CTD matched maturity swap (swap start date 8 Dec 2025, swap end date 15 Aug 2034 vs 6s Euribor) (Bund spread narrower) versus buying 442 Dec25 Buxl futures versus paying €48.6mn CTD matched maturity swap (swap start date 8 Dec 2025, swap end date 15th Aug 2056 vs 6s Euribor) (Buxl spread widener) to enter into a Bund/Buxl swap spread curve steepener at -37.5bp;

- Hold Sep25 Schatz ESTR swap spread widenerStay long 1000 Sep25 Schatz futures versus paying €105.4m CTD maturity matched ESTR swaps (swap start date 8 Sep 2025, swap maturity date 10 Jun 2027) to remain in a swap spread widener at -10.1bp versus entry level of -9.0bp; P&L since inception (11th July 2025): -1.1bp of yield

Buy €100mn 2.47% 1Yx5Y straddles (100% risk weight, notification date 1st Sep 2026, maturity date 3 Sep 2031) versus selling €100mn 2.38% 6Mx5Y straddles (72% risk weight, notification date 2nd March 2026, maturity date 4 March 2031) to enter into a weighted expiry curve steepener at a weighted implied spread of 1.3bp/day. This trade requires active delta hedging and is long vega/short gamma at inception;

x.labels: 1M MA of German RFR specialness*; bp

values.Comment: European Central Bank officials are increasingly convinced they can keep interest rates unchanged in September, according to people familiar with the matter who don't see the trade deal between Brussels and Washington causing major economic concerns.
I think the bar is high. So it needs a lot to convince me to change monetary policy.
Inflation is for now in a good place. Any insurance cut just for its own sake wouldn't be necessary [though] the ECB must of course be mindful of the risks.
We've seen good news, we've seen bad news, but not sufficiently big news to lead to a rethink of what we would need to do. I think we are still in a good place.

[Higher levies will only have] a small impact [on GDP]. The economy is increasingly back to potential. Growth is relatively modest, but resilient and on its way up with the fundamentals such as consumption and investment looking good at the moment. The ECB expects only a very minor impact on inflation [from the trade deal].

Uncertainty about the effects of geopolitics and the trade war nevertheless clouds the economic outlook. [Inflation is in the short term slowing below the 2% target as a result of cheaper energy, a stronger euro, and the slowdown in services inflation].
